data.title: Lissy Taylor: Your Girl – Single Review
data.meta_description: Stoke-on-Trent based alt-rocker Lissy Taylor's most recent release is the radiantly catchy single Your Girl.
data.text:
Lissy Taylor: Your Girl

(Self Released)

Download/Streaming

Out Now

Following a flurry of summer festival appearances including Truck Festival and the main stage at Y Not Festival, Stoke-on-Trent based alt-rocker Lissy Taylor releases the radiantly catchy new single Your Girl.

Lissy continues to showcasing brilliant pop-rock songwriting that evokes both Avril Lavigne and beabadoobee which first brought her to the attention of Louder Than War a couple of years ago with her single Healer.

Latest single, Your Girl, harks back to early 2000s classics while maintaining a breezy, contemporary freshness. The track features a tight, guitar-driven backdrop under Lissy’s charismatic lead vocals, where her smoky, sultry tone glides above the instrumentation, navigating the playful yet empowering lyrics with a summery feel, highlighted by the silky-smooth production of Tayte Nickols.

The single does a brilliant job of capturing the full-band energy of Lissy’s live shows while maintaining a commercial edge, particularly through its infectious chorus. It’s a brilliant example of what Lissy is capable of.

Thematically, Your Girl explores independence and empowerment, celebrating single life. Lissy explains: “I wrote it after a breakup, thinking, yes, I could be your girl, but I can be anything. I really wanted to capture the confidence and empowerment of being single.”

Lissy Taylor, a regular on Louder Than War Radio, has already earned numerous accolades, including a recent win at Manchester City FC’s Battle Of The Bands—an achievement that John Kennedy jokingly remarked made her “the best artist in Manchester” while introducing her at Truck Festival. With more music on the horizon, Lissy is poised for a big second half of 2024.

Find Lissy on Facebook, X/Twitter and Instagram

All words by Simon Lucas-Hughes. More writing by Simon Lucas-Hughes can be found at his author’s archive.
